Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Differentiated Household Recovery Post-Hurricane Harvey

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Award.AbstractNarration:
This qualitative research project will be conducted among Hurricane Harvey repeat and first-time evacuees who are relocated in the Houston area. The goal is to capture people's early reactions, feelings, observations, and household negotiations as they plan how to move forward. The researchers particularly want to understand how past experiences with floods and hurricanes affect current planning and decision-making. The researchers anticipate that Houstonian household responses to their third flood in three years is changed by that previous experience of flooding and by memories of past hurricanes, including Ike (2008), Rita (2005), and Tropical Storm Allison (2001). Harvey was not just a catastrophic event, it was the cap on a cumulative 17 year series of flood and hurricane incidents. The researchers are particularly interested in the question of whether flood-fatigued households will have less conflict over decisions to stay or leave than do households without prior flood experience. Findings from this research will be used to develop appropriate primary and secondary interventions to improve the provision of relief and support services in future disasters. Findings also will help improve understanding of how people adjust their assessments over time, which will enable policy makers to create appropriate interventions to help households deal with repeat disasters.

Data collection for this study will consist of digitally-recorded face-to-face in-depth audio interviews, field notes, and archival sources (newspaper reports, internet sites dedicated to Hurricane Harvey evacuees, government and NGO reports). A stratified sample of 80 men and women from 40 households that represent with different backgrounds and circumstances will be recruited to participate in this study. Half of the sample will be from a neighborhood that has not been flooded in recent memory, and half of the sample will from a separate neighborhood that that has been flooded many times. Ten key informant stakeholders, affiliated with Houston government agencies, non-profit groups, and religious organizations, will also be interviewed. The audio-taped interviews will be transcribed and the digital files, along with the field notes and relevant archival documents, will be coded for themes and emergent ideas that will be followed up on in later interviews. The expected outcomes of this research project are: 1) insights into the types of interventions and policies that will help post-disaster households remain viable; and, 2) improved social science theory about factors that produce effective household risk assessment, coping, and survival strategies after repeated and cumulative disaster experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To examine differences in the decision making of households affected only by Hurricane Harvey vs. households with some prior flooding experience plus Hurricane Harvey, we interviewed several dozen people in two neighborhoods of Houston—one in the northeast (Harvey only), and one in the southwest (Harvey and another flood). We used a convenience sampling technique, including respondent-driven sampling (referrals) to find people that fit our criteria of: 1) homeowners and renters, 2) prior flood experience and no flood experience, and 3) African American ethnicity (although we included a few Latino households at the end due to difficulty finding households with prior experience with flooding. Our goal was 40 households or 20 previously affected by flooding and 20 only affected by Hurricane Harvey. We interviewed 55 people from 35 households. Previously affected households totaled 20 (34 interviews), and Harvey-only households numbered 15 (21 interviews). We interviewed 35 individuals from 20 owner-occupied households flooded by Hurricane Harvey and seven of them had national flood insurance. Neighborhoods and apartment complexes were targeted based on information from study participants and residents, newspaper reports, archives of past flooding (2015 Memorial Day Flood, 2016 Tax Day Flood), and information from community organizations.

Many residents had difficulty considering the concept of decision making during and after the storm and instead described their experiences in terms of actions forced by rapidly diminishing opportunities. After the initial displacement of many at the time of the flooding, some returned to their homes and apartments and stayed there while making repairs, those in apartments moved upstairs to new accommodations, some moved to different apartments, others found FEMA housing support, some stayed with families, lived in cars, still others lived in apartments without walls and only sheets separating them from their neighbors, and two lived under a bridge. Regardless of housing post-Harvey, many reported anxiety and stress responses to storms and their general situation. The elderly and others traumatized by their evacuation from their homes were the most likely to report mental health issues.

            We noted particularly small networks of each of these households in these poor urban working-class AA communities. Household resilience and decision making was improved by the strength and geographic density of social networks: 1) flood victims most often received information on how to proceed with recovery and access services and aid via word-of-mouth,  2) temporary housing provided by network members influenced flood victims’ mental health and ability to engage in recovery activities, 3) material and psychological support through mutual aid improved recovery outcomes for households with strong network ties, and 4) the strength of relationships between victims and their employers and colleagues were especially influential of victims’ capacity for decision making and recovery outcomes.

            People faced challenges in navigating the system after Hurricane Harvey and lacked confidence in government and organizations distributing aid because: 1) there were different timelines and procedures for different stakeholders (e.g., FEMA vs. state vs. local vs. actual communities in need) and gaps in local knowledge and understanding; 2) low-income neighborhoods and households, especially the elderly and those with the most substantial damage, who had limited access to information about where and how to get a case manager, access resources, and get assistance were targeted by predatory developers and contractors; 3) it was difficult to navigate the bureaucracy of organizations responsible for distributing aid results in diminishing capacity for personal recovery over time; 4) flood victims were taken advantage of by developers, lenders, landlords, and contractors; and 5) there was a common sentiment that repeated flooding and ineffective aid demonstrated lack of interest or ability to prevent or ameliorate flood damage in  disadvantaged neighborhoods

            Factors reportedly negatively affecting capacity for decision making and recovery outcomes were: mental and somatic illness; financial and transportation demands of receiving adequate care; history of trauma increasing negative emotional affect (e.g., veterans); children or elderly living in the household; age of household head; history of substance abuse, past or current incarceration. In terms of our main hypothesis about the difference between those with prior flood experience and those hit for the first time, there appear to be some differences in wellbeing. Those having prior flood experience suffer lower levels of several posttraumatic stress symptoms (avoiding external reminders, memories of it make you lose track of what’s going on, acting as if it were happening again, and feeling upset by reminders). Previous flood experience influenced decision making leading up to, during, and after Harvey –

  • Before: whether to have flood insurance, whether or not to evacuate, how to prepare
  • During: when to leave home, how to evacuate, and emotional wherewithal
  • After: how and when to begin accessing aid and services, rebuilding process, outcome expectation, whether or not to move

There was a desire for developing sustainable and equitable responses, recovery, and resilience, and not just meeting acute, immediate needs after disaster.
